name: Islamic Services Foundation
theoryOfChange: By providing high-quality Islamic education and incubating social-change organizations, ISF empowers the community to thrive across generations.

components.evidence: Accepts zakat (+2); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Islamic identity (+1)
components.improvement_suggestion: Add a dedicated zakat page or program and highlight humanitarian dimensions of your work
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

alignment.rationale: Alignment 22/50: LOW Muslim donor fit, religious cultural cause area

components.improvement_suggestion: Build working capital reserves to 1-3 months of operating expenses
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Document a clear theory of change with causal pathway
components.name: Theory of Change

judge_issues.message: The rationale mentions a "high cost per beneficiary" which is not entirely accurate. While the cost per beneficiary is $13,220.62, the rationale states it is "moderated by a high cost per beneficiary and limited external verification of its broader impact." The cost per beneficiary is actually average for the RELIGIOUS_CULTURAL cause area, as stated in the score details.

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Islamic Services Foundation earns 50/100 due to good impact and moderate alignment, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied).

all_citations.claim: The Islamic Services Foundation was founded in 1989 and operates schools and endowment programs.
The organization is Zakat-eligible and provides multiple donation options.
ISF offers various volunteer opportunities for community engagement.
The organization is a registered 501(c)(3) with specific profile metadata.
ISF reported total revenue of $14,235,728, a 99.5% program expense ratio, 14.5 months of working capital, and $0.00 fundraising efficiency.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization demonstrates excellent financial health and efficiency, though its overall score is moderated by a high cost per beneficiary and limited external verification of its broader impact.
areas_for_improvement: High cost per beneficiary relative to other direct provision services.
Limited external data confidence and third-party verification of impact metrics.

dimension_explanations.alignment: The organization shows a moderate alignment score, serving a specific religious and cultural niche with a long track record since 1989 [1]. While it provides essential community services, the donor fit is currently rated as low based on available alignment metrics [4][5].
dimension_explanations.impact: ISF maintains a direct provision model through its schools and scholarship programs, reporting a total revenue of $14,235,728 [5]. While financial health is robust with a 99.5% program expense ratio, the impact score reflects a high cost per beneficiary of approximately $13,220 and medium data confidence [1][5].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Islamic Services Foundation is a long-standing non-profit dedicated to empowering the Muslim community through educational excellence and sustainable endowment initiatives.
strengths: Exceptional program expense ratio of 99.5%, ensuring nearly all funds reach core services [5].
High fundraising efficiency with $0.00 spent to raise every $1 [5].
Strong liquidity with 14.5 months of working capital available [5].
baseline_narrative.summary: founded in 1989, the Islamic Services Foundation (ISF) operates comprehensive educational programs and an endowment fund to serve the Muslim community [1][5]. The organization is Zakat-eligible and offers various engagement opportunities through donations and volunteerism [2][3].

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization demonstrates excellent financial health and efficiency, though its overall score is moderated by a high cost per beneficiary and limited external verification of its broader impact.

areas_for_improvement.detail: The average cost of <cite id="17">$13,220.62 per beneficiary</cite> is high compared to other direct service providers, reflecting the intensive nature of private schooling.
The board structure shows <cite id="18">only 15% independent members</cite>, which is below the standard for highly transparent non-profits.

bbb_assessment.summary: Financial data indicates strong efficiency, but full BBB accreditation is not on file.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The high cost is typical for accredited K-12 private education, and the foundation's large net assets mitigate financial risk.
risk_factors: <cite id="18">Only 15% of the board is independent</cite>
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="18">low board independence</cite> and a <cite id="17">high cost-per-student model</cite> that may not appeal to donors seeking high-volume impact.

confidence.data_freshness: Financial data from 2023; Annual reports from 2022-2023
confidence.notes: Financial efficiency is extremely high, but governance transparency is a limiting factor.

alignment.explanation: The organization is <cite id="9">Zakat-eligible</cite> and serves a <cite id="20">niche religious-cultural cause</cite> that is often underserved by secular philanthropy.
alignment.improvement: The foundation could <cite id="21">add a dedicated Zakat transparency page</cite> to explicitly detail how Zakat funds are segregated and utilized.

credibility.explanation: ISF is a long-standing institution <cite id="1">founded in 1989</cite> with a <cite id="10">strong 37-year track record</cite>. While it lacks a full Charity Navigator rating, its <cite id="4">Form 990 data</cite> confirms significant assets and consistent growth.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the charity should <cite id="18">increase the percentage of independent board members</cite> and publish audited financial statements.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by <cite id="3">direct provision of education</cite> and a <cite id="5">100% program ratio</cite>. However, the <cite id="17">$13,220 cost per beneficiary</cite> limits the total number of individuals served.
impact.improvement: Documenting a <cite id="19">clear theory of change</cite> with causal pathways would help demonstrate the long-term societal value of its graduates.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade B - Verified outcomes in annual reports

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct provision of services and student financial aid

rich_narrative.headline: The Islamic Services Foundation is a long-standing non-profit dedicated to empowering the Muslim community through educational excellence and sustainable endowment initiatives.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who value the establishment of permanent Islamic institutional infrastructure and want to support high-quality private education and endowments.
donor_motivations: Want to support long-term community sustainability through endowments
Value 100% efficiency where every dollar goes to programs
Seek to fulfill Zakat through established educational institutions
giving_considerations: Focus is on high-depth impact per student rather than high-breadth reach
Large asset base means the organization is very stable but has less urgent 'survival' needs
Donations support both local schooling and international relief partnerships
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking high-volume, low-cost interventions (e.g., $1 per meal) or those who require a majority-independent board for governance comfort.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: The organization publishes detailed <cite id="7">annual reports with specific beneficiary counts</cite> and outcome metrics for its schools and missions.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: ISF creates impact by providing high-quality Islamic and secular education, fostering a new generation of leaders, and maintaining an endowment to ensure these services remain available regardless of economic shifts.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that the high cost of education translates into tangible student success and community leadership.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: While the endowment is strong, expanding school capacity and scholarships requires ongoing capital.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by a <cite id="5">99.5% program expense ratio</cite> compared to a <cite id="22">peer median of 80%</cite>.

similar_organizations.differentiator: More focus on social services and activism
similar_organizations.name: Inner-City Muslim Action Network

strengths.detail: The organization directs <cite id="5">100.0% of its expenses to programs</cite> and spends <cite id="6">$0.00 per $1 raised</cite>.
ISF has achieved a <cite id="10">3-year revenue CAGR of 23.2%</cite>, growing from $9.3 million in 2021 to over $14.2 million in 2023.
The foundation maintains <cite id="11">14.5 months of working capital</cite>, providing significant stability for its endowment and school operations.

strengths_deep_dive: The Islamic Services Foundation's financial health is anchored by its massive asset base and efficient capital management. With <cite id="12">total assets exceeding $15.9 million</cite> and a net asset growth from $11.1 million to <cite id="13">$13.8 million over three years</cite>, the foundation is well-positioned for long-term sustainability. Its educational impact is tangible, evidenced by a <cite id="14">graduating class of 72 students</cite> and the provision of <cite id="15">8 full-ride scholarships</cite> in recent cycles. Furthermore, the organization has successfully diversified its income, generating <cite id="16">$10.4 million from program service revenue</cite> alongside $3.5 million in contributions, indicating a self-sustaining model for its educational institutions.
rich_narrative.summary: Founded in <cite id="1">1989</cite>, the Islamic Services Foundation (ISF) is a Texas-based non-profit dedicated to the long-term empowerment of the Muslim community through <cite id="2">educational excellence and sustainable endowment initiatives</cite>. The organization operates a diverse portfolio of services, including <cite id="3">ISF Schools, a Qur’an Hifz Program, and student financial aid</cite>, alongside maintaining prayer spaces for the community. In the 2023 fiscal year, ISF demonstrated significant financial scale, reporting <cite id="4">total revenue of $14,235,728</cite>, a substantial increase from previous years. A defining characteristic of ISF is its exceptional financial efficiency; the organization maintains a <cite id="5">program expense ratio of 99.5%</cite>, ensuring that every dollar of public support is directed toward its core mission. This efficiency is further highlighted by its <cite id="6">fundraising efficiency of $0.00 spent to raise every $1</cite>, a rare metric among religious and cultural institutions. Beyond education, ISF has expanded its humanitarian reach through strategic partnerships, such as <cite id="7">providing 196,650 meals via cooperation with ANERA</cite> and conducting medical missions that <cite id="8">treated over 1,000 children</cite> in 2023. The organization is <cite id="9">Zakat-eligible</cite>, offering donors a verified avenue to fulfill their religious obligations while supporting domestic educational infrastructure and international relief efforts.
